Description

Physical description

medal with ribbon The obverse is a bronze cross with crossed swords between the arms. In the centre is a female head with the transcription REPUBLIQUE FRANCAISE around the head and a spray of laurel underneath. The reverse has the dates 1914 1918 in the centre. The ribbon has 6 green stripes and 5 thinner red stripes, with red edges. There are marks on the ribbon indicating it may have once had a star device attached, with would indicate a Mention in Despatch.

History note

Louis Yves Duroure was born 11.12.1886 at Quimperlé, Finistère - a Breton. Came to England c1910-11 to work as a hairdresser. Married Hilda Vera Sarah Gardiner Gurney in 1912, the daughter of the owner of a gentleman's outfitters in Hockley, Essex, where he first worked. Eventually he worked at hotels including the Savoy, Piccadily, and Cecil - known to customers as 'Mr Louis'. By 1914 they had one child, Louise, who is shown in a copy photograph (see file) as Louis returns from the war. Louis served as a soldat in the French Army during the First World War, as a sniper, and was awarded the Medaille Militaire and the Croix de Guerre; he was credited with shooting down a German aeroplane near Reims in 1917, from which the clock was presented to him as a souvenir (modern mount). Another copy photograph shows Louis in the uniform of the 63rd Infantry Regiment, with his sergeant, reputedly killed the next day. Later had 3 more children - Lou, Rae and finally Julian (born 1936). The medals etc donated by Rae, who was accompanied to the museum by her nephew Colin, son of Louise.
